{{also|Welcher}} ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|welsher}} ''(UK)'' ===Etymology=== {{suffix|en|welch|er}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{audio|en|En-au-welcher.ogg|Audio (AU)}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # One who [[welch]]es. # {{lb|en|British|offensive|_|slang}} A [[Welshman]] or person of [[Welsh]] descent. ====Translations==== {{trans-top}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t-needed|cmn}} * Finnish: {{t|fi|[[maksaa|maksamatta]] [[jättäjä]]}} * French: {{t-needed|fr}} {{trans-mid}} * German: {{t-needed|de}} * Russian: {{t-needed|ru}} * Spanish: {{t-needed|es}} * Thai: {{t-needed|th}} {{trans-bottom}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|welih}}, {{m|goh|wilih}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*hwilīkaz}}. Compare {{cog|en|which}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈvɛlçɐ/}} * {{IPA|de|[ˈvɛʎ̞çɐ]|[ˈvɛɪ̯çɐ]}} {{a|regional variants}} * {{audio|de|De-welcher.ogg|Audio}} ===Determiner=== {{head|de|determiner}} # {{lb|de|interrogative}} [[which]]; [[what]] #: '''''Welche''' Farbe hat dein Kleid?'' #:: '''What''' colour is your dress? #: '''''Welches''' Buch in diesem Regal hast du am öftesten gelesen?'' #:: '''Which''' book on this shelf have you read most often? # {{lb|de|relative|literary}} [[which]] #: ''Er vergaß, die letzte Kugel aus dem Lauf zu nehmen, '''welcher''' Fehler ihn das Leben kosten würde.'' #:: He forgot to remove the last bullet from the barrel, '''which''' mistake would cost him his life. ===Pronoun=== {{head|de|pronoun}} # {{lb|de|interrogative}} [[which]] (one) #: ''Hier sind zwei Jacken, '''welche''' ist deine?'' #:: There are two jackets here, '''which one''' is yours? # {{lb|de|relative|literary}} [[that]]; [[which]]; [[who]]; [[whom]] #: ''Der Mann, '''welchen''' sie als ihren Nachbarn erkannte, lag tot auf dem Bürgersteig.'' #:: The man, '''whom''' she recognized to be her neighbour, was lying dead on the pavement. ====Usage notes==== * ''Welcher'' as a relative pronoun is virtually never used in the vernacular. It occurs more often in literary German, but overusing it is a typical trait of a pretentious style (generally corrected by editors). The normal relative pronoun in all registers of German is {{m|de|der}} and its forms. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-pronoun|welcher|welche|welches|welche|welches|welcher|welches|welcher|welchem|welcher|welchem|welchen|welchen|welche|welches|welche}}
